Class HangmanGame

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • java.awt.Window
          • java.awt.Frame
            • javax.swing.JFrame
              • HangmanGame
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants

    public class HangmanGame
extends javax.swing.JFrame
    HangmanGame is the main JFrame for the game that shows all progress to the user. It is made up of several labels, a DashDisplay, and two text areas for the user to enter input as guesses to the game. Each game is started with randomized 3 letter word, and the user has 6 guesses to attempt to win the game.
    See Also:
    HangmanGame(String[]), JFrame, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • HangmanGame

        public HangmanGame(java.lang.String[] words)
        The HangmanGame constructor initializes the labels needed to be shown on the screen with proper font and alignment. It also initializes the text areas, and assigns them an actionListener defined below, and a key listener, sometimes referred to as a "chomp" to remove any extra letters past their preset width. An instance of DashDisplay is added to the JFrame to display the user's progress. These elements are then all added to the JFrame with proper spacing in-between.
        Parameters:
        words - the three letter word for attempting to guess.
        See Also:
        DashDisplay, HangmanGame.letterGuessActionListener, HangmanGame.wordGuessActionListener

    • Method Detail

      • badGuess

        public void badGuess()
        Removes a guess from how many the user has left and notifies them of their incorrect guess. If guesses hit zero, the function notifies the user that they have lost, and calls endGame() to end the game.
        See Also:
        endGame()

      • goodGuess

        public void goodGuess()
        Notifies the user that they have made a correct guess, and if their guess happened to complete the word, notifies them of their win, and calls endGame().
        See Also:
        endGame()

      • endGame

        public void endGame()
        Deactivates the two text areas for guessing, and reflects the complete word within the dashDisplay by making a call to it's method progressUpdate().
        See Also:
        DashDisplay
